Variation Example: A young woman is forced by her parents to marry a clergyman even though she has fallen in love with a poor boy (soldier). When the young man (returning from a journey) comes unrecognized to her wedding, the priest jokingly marries him to the girl He reveals himself. In German variants Friedrich II requests a mock wedding between the bride & a soldier.

A young woman (princess) has fallen in love with a poor young man, but her parents make her marry another man. The rejected wooer leaves for a journey. At her wedding the girl falls down dead (feigns death). Her lover returns, resuscitates her, & marries her. Or, he secretly escapes with her & a wax doll is buried in her grave.

Classifications: The Girl Who Could Not Keep the Secret
Variation Example: A young man leaves his bride because she cannot keep secrets. He finds a new bride. At the betrothal the first fiancée says that she still hopes to marry him. When the new fiancée learns that the young man had abandoned the former bride because of her talkativeness, she boasts of her superiority in keeping silent: that she has concealed all her previous lovers (the killing of her children). The young man decides to marry his first bride.

A marquis (king) who loves his freedom marries because his subjects demand it. He chooses a wife of the lower class (named Griselda), & demands that she promise always to be obedient. When she has given birth to two children, he tests her obedience by taking them away making her believe that he has killed them. After 15 years, he casts her off & orders her adult children (who had grown up in another family) to come home. He pretends to marry Griselda’s daughter, & makes Griselda serve her at the wed-ding feast. When Griselda accepts even this humiliation, he explains everything to her (that everything had been a test), & takes her again as his wife.

A young man complains that he possesses brains but no money. He decides to spend all his hard-earned money to buy a wife. The wife teaches him how to enclose precious stones in bricks. He takes them to the king (czar) as a gift & receives a reward.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A man who is taken into slavery in Turkey wears a shirt that remains white as long as his wife at home remains true to him. The sultan sends a messenger to seduce the wife, but in vain. Disguised as a pilgrim (monk), she reaches the sultan’s court. Through her harp-playing & her singing she wins the sul-tan’s favor. He presents her with a (three) Christian slave, who is in fact her husband. When the husband has returned home he wonders what happened to his wife. She arrives in her pilgrim dress & identifies herself as his rescuer. (2) A king goes to a foreign land, where he is thrown into prison. His wife disguises herself as a gusli-player, goes to the hostile king & receives his permission to take one of the prisoners with her. She chooses her husband. The husband does not recognize her & later reproaches his wife for not trying to help him. The truth is discovered.

Classifications: The Wife Who Would Not be Beaten
Variation Example: A prince (merchant’s son) says he will marry only a woman who will submit to a beating each day. When he is married his wife refuses to allow him to beat her, saying he does not support her (but her father does). The prince sets out to win his fortune but is enslaved (loses all his fortune, must work at menial tasks). His wife disguises herself as a man & frees him (by winning back all he had lost) She wins chess games by releasing mice which are chased by a trained cat (she tricks the cheaters, she wins the wager). She secures tokens from her husband. At home, when the husband falsely boasts of his exploits, the wife displays the tokens. Her husband never beats her again.
A man learns a trade (basket-making, painting) in order to support a wife. She is taken away by a sea captain. Years later, she recognizes her husband when she sees his baskets displayed.

Classifications: Wager on the Faithfulness of the Servant
Variation Example: A man (king, lord, farmer) boasts that his servant (shep-herd, farmhand) would never tell a lie. His neighbor (foreign king, visitor, friend, governor) makes a wager on the faithfulness of the servant. In order to test the servant he is sent with a letter to the neighbor’s wife (queen, daughter) where the woman makes him drunk & seduces him. In some variants the maidservant (daughter, wife) is sent to the sherpherd & persuades him to give her in return for her favors a lamb or the golden horns (liver, skin, meat) of his master’s best ox (sheep, horse). Or he is made to believe that he lost his master’s pro perty by gambling while drunk. Later the servant rehearses how he could justify his behavior to his master: He puts his stick into the earth with his hat on top & speaks to it. But all possible lies seem inadequate to him, so he decides to tell the truth. Thus his master wins the wager (the servant is rewarded for his honesty).

A contract entitles the lender (Jew, merchant, usurer, nobleman) of a sum of money (that has been used to woo or to buy a woman) to cut a pound of flesh (eye, head, single limbs) from the debtor’s (Christian or Muslim merchant, goldsmith, Jew nobleman) body if the loan is not repaid in time. In some variants the husband goes abroad for some time, & other men try to seduce his wife. She deceives them all & takes their money in payment for keeping the matter secret. When the time limit has been reached, the case is brought to the judge (pope, king, sultan, the debtor’s wife disguised as judge, another woman in man’s clothes). In some variants, before the judgment has been executed, the creditor is offered the money if he will forgo the pound of flesh, but he does not agree. The judgment formally favors the creditor but adds some impossible conditions: when cutting the flesh of the debtor he must take the exact amount (he must not shed blood), otherwise he will be punished severely. Thereupon the creditor re nounces his demand to mutilate the debtor (and is punished in addition).
A knight (merchant) with heavy debts dies. The ruler (creditor) wants to sell the bed for a high price, saying that it must be very good since the knight slept well in it despite his debts.
A (sleeping) girl (young man) has a snake in her bosom. All her relatives refuse to help remove it. Finally her lover finds (removes) the snake, which turns to gold.

Classifications: The Man Who Deserted his Wife
Variation Example: A man (prince, merchant) marries a woman, intending to revenge himself for an insult. He deserts her untouched before the wedding night (imprisons her), & sets her the seemingly impossible task of bearing him a son (to get a foal of his mare or to fill a sealed box with gold) & leaves her. She follows him in disguise (first in man’s clothes) & has a love-affair with him without being recognized (three times). She gives birth to a son (three children). Her husband returns, intending to marry another woman. Upon seeing her son (children, tokens) he realizes that she has fulfilled the task. They are reconciled & he sends the other woman away.
A princess (only daughter) is kept isolated in a crystal palace. A prince finds her (sees her from far away) & they fall in love, but he leaves without asking to marry her.

The king admires (falls in love with) the (sleeping) wife of a courtier (knight) & leaves his glove (ring) on her bed. She is suspected of unfaithfulness. The king invites the courtier & his wife to a banquet, where all must tell their adventures. The king & the woman do so in rhyme, & the husband realizes their (his wife’s) innocence

A wife falsely accused of giving away money (to her lover). Her husband threatens to kill her but their child says that the pig (ox) has eaten the money. The man kills the pig & finds the money. He begs his wife’s forgiveness.

While a prince is in the service of another king, his sister must govern the country. However, seduced by a certain knight, the princess substitutes a maidservant. As proof of his seduction (rape) the knight shows a cut finger (hair, knowledge of the birthmarks) to the brother. The prince repudiates his sister, but she justifies herself by giving proof of her chastity. Her innocence becomes apparent & the knight is punished

A young man boasts of his numerous friends. His father intends to test them. A slaughtered animal (hog, statue, tub) is hidden in a sack (in a dark corner of the house). The young man pretends to have killed a person unintentionally. When he asks his friends to help him bury the corpse they all re fuse. Only his father’s “half-friend” is ready to share the danger with him (remains true to him in his feigned trouble)

Classifications: The Ghoulish Schoolmaster & the Stone of Pity
Variation Example: A princess accidentally sees her school -master eating a corpse (a human being). She escapes. This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A princess marries a prince abroad & gives birth to several children, who are kidnapped by the ghoulish teacher. The teacher leaves blood (other signs) that point at the mother as murderer of her children, she is imprisoned. When the prince goes on a journey, his imprisoned wife asks him to bring her a stone of patience (and a knife), which he does. The prince overhears his wife telling her sorrows to the stone. The stone swells & finally bursts because it cannot bear the sorrow (and she tries to kill herself with the knife). The prince embraces his innocent slandered wife, & the cannibal teacher brings back her children. (2) The princess finds a sleeping prince who can only be awakened if she would care for him for a certain period (seven years, seven months, seven days). Just before the end of the time limit, the princess delegates her task to a female slave & falls asleep. When the prince awakens & sees the slave he thinks that she has saved his life. He marries her, & the princess becomes her maidservant . The princess asks for a knife & a stone of patience. The king’s marshal overhears her telling her story to the swelling stone. When the prince listens, the stone bursts out of pity. When she is about to kill herself with the knife, the prince interferes. They marry & the slave girl is punished

Classifications: The Lecherous Holy Man & the Maiden in a Box
Variation Example: A holy man (trusted adviser) falls in love with a beautiful girl, but she spurns his advances. He convinces the girl’s father (husband) that she is un chaste (will bring calamities to the kingdom) & that she should be placed in a box & cast into the river (delivered to him). He instructs his followers to bring the box to him, to leave it in his room, to securely lock the doors, & to ignore any sounds that may come from his room. A prince (other helper) finds the box before it falls into the hands of the holy man’s followers, removes the girl, & puts a mad dog (tiger, wild animal) into the box. The holy man is torn to pieces when he opens the box. The girl marries her rescuer & is reconciled with her family.

Classifications: The Orphan Girl & Her Cruel Sister-in-Law
Variation Example: A young girl is left by her seven brothers while they go on a trip in the care of her seven sisters-in-law. They set tasks for her, hoping she will be unable to perform them so that they can punish her. She is helped by various animals: to carry a large load of sticks from the forest without using a rope, a helpful snake winds around the sticks; to fetch a tigress’s milk, the tigress willingly gives it; to fetch water in a sieve, frogs fill the holes in the sieve; to gather seeds scattered in a field, birds help her. While she is performing the last task, the brothers appear. The sisters-in-law are punished.

(The Speechless Maiden. The Doll Bride.) In order to evade a prophecy that a princess would be impregnated by the sun & bear a child, she is confined in a tower. Nevertheless the prophecy is fulfilled. The daughter of the sun is exposed in a garden & rescued by a prince. In some variants a childless couple, after having a dream, build them selves a girl (doll) from wood (lime, paste). A prince wants to marry her. On the way to the prince the (mistress of the) sea ex-changes the doll with her own daughter, whom the prince marries. The prince does not recognize her extraordinary origin, so she stays mute & rejects him. The prince marries three women of royal blood, but they all die when they try to imitate the abilities of the first woman (e.g. objects obey her commands, her cut nose grows again, when she puts her finger in hot oil cooked fish appear, etc.). When the prince feigns an illness the girl cares for him, reveals her origin, & consents to the marriage. In other variants the prince overhears objects quarreling & learns how he should address her: daughter of the sun (daughter of the sea, etc.). When he calls her in this way she speaks & marries him.

A young man (only son) is doomed to an early death: He is predestined to die on his wedding day. In some variants Norns (an angel, death) predict his death for the third day after his birth (another day). God (saints, St. George, Demetrius) intercedes with the Norns (death), & they agree that the young man may live if another person is willing to die for him or to give him half (a part) of his own remaining lifetime. The members of his family (his parents) refuse, but his bride is ready to die for him. God saves both the young man & the woman who is willing to sacrifice herself, & punishes the hard-hearted parents.

Pyramus & Thisbe, children of neighboring families, are in love, but their fathers have forbidden them to meet. They use a crack in the wall between their houses to communicate in secret. One day they decide to meet on the following night outside the city under a mulberry tree. When Thisbe arrives she is frightened by a lion & hides in a cave. Before the lion goes away, he chews on a scarf that Thisbe had dropped, & leaves marks of blood on it.Pyramus comes and, seeing the scarf (other evidence), believes that Thisbe is dead & kills himself. Thisbe returns, finds her lover dead, & kills herself with his sword. The blood-red berries of the mulberry tree commemorate the lovers’ unhappy end.

A princess refuses all (one) who come to her as suitors without giving a reason. She ridicules them & calls them ugly names (Thrushbeard). Her father, angry at this behavior, decides that she has to marry the next man who comes, even if he is a beggar. The last rejected wooer decides to take revenge. He appears disguised as a beggar (in arrangement with her father) & the princess is forced into marriage (the beggar purchases the right to spend three nights with her; she becomes pregnant). The couple runs away (is banished by the king). On the way the prince in disguise humilates his new wife. She has to beg & sell in the marketplace, she has to work in the kitchen of his own castle & he even forces her to steal. During a celebration (supposedly the wedding of the once reject ed prince) he, in his true character as prince, exposes her as a thief before all the people at court. Only then does he reveal himself to her as her beggar husband. He forgives her for her haugh-tiness & their official wedding is celebrated.

A princess is to be married to whoever wins a tourna-ment. She mocks a knight who eats half a pear without peeling it (and without offering her the other half) calling him, “Knight of the half-pear”. He disguises himself as a deaf-mute fool & lies down before the palace. He is invited to sit at the fireplace inside the palace. When his penis becomes erect he is summoned by the princess & has sexual intercourse with her. The next day he is thrown out & returns to the tournament in his former knight’s dress where he alludes clearly to the night’s events. He marries the embarrassed princess.

A man marries the youngest of three sisters, who is strongminded & shrewish. In order to demonstrate how he punishes disobedience, he shoots his dog & his horse when they do not obey his (nonsensical) orders. He brings his wife to sub-mission. In a wager with his brothers about which has the most obedient wife (sisters-in-law) it becomes evident that only his wife is truly obedient. He wins the bet.
A lazy wife (daughter, daughter-in-law) learns (is forced) to work by the measures taken by her husband (father, father-in-law). She gets something to eat only after she has finished her work.

A lazy woman does not perform her household work (she deceives her husband by pretending to have finished it). She always shows her husband the same spool of thread, until one day she has only one dirty (no) dress left. Her husband takes her (naked) enveloped in a bundle of straw (animal skin) to a wedding (festivity). The bundle (animal skin) falls apart & the woman stands naked before the public. Thus she is cured of her laziness & becomes industrious from then on. In some variants the woman wears a very dirty dress or is naked. When she sees her husband coming back from the market, she thinks he is bringing a new shirt for her, but instead of a shirt he is carrying a white goose in his arms.
Quick-Tempered Maiden finds a man equally quick-tempered. Misc. Type.
The bad mother-in-law who lets her daughter-in-law go hungry is punished (the voice of a hidden clergyman threatens her with the devil). She reforms.

Classifications: The Wicked Queen Reformed by Whipping by a Cobbler
Variation Example: While asleep, the wicked queen is made to exchange places (by an angel, magician, ordinary man) with the humble cobbler’s wife (who is always beaten by her husband). When the queen wakes up, she thinks herself in hell. The cobbler reforms her by his whippings & from then on she obeys her husband.
This misc. type comprises various tales dealing with a person who is given a precept (of various types) by another person. The precept is observed or disregarded.

A dying man gives three precepts to his son (to another person). Each variant includes three of the following precepts: (1) Never tell a secret to a woman. (2) Do not make friends with (trust) a policeman (soldier, ruler). (3) Do not plant a thorny tree (without permission) on your property. (4) Do not adopt a child (godchild, orphan, child of thief). (5) Do not visit your friends (parents) too often. (6) Avoid the house of a red-bearded man. (7) Do not marry a woman from abroad (be careful in your choice of a wife). (8) Do not let your wife go to a wedding accompanied only by her parents (do not let her go for a long visit to her parents). (9) Do not bargain for your horse, do not make it run down a hill. (10) Do not lend your horse The son (person) disregards his father’s precepts (he thinks they are nonsensical) & suffers misfortune (in order to test the precepts, he acts against them). (1) After burying (hiding) an animal (human being) at a special place he tells his wife about it. When they quarrel & he beats her, she calls him a murderer & he is arrested. (2) His friend arrests him without listening to the true version of the event (he condemns him by jumping to conclusions without identifying the victim). (3) His turban sticks in the thorns of a tree, & his friend forces him to present himself without it. (The thorn tree he planted causes for a quarrel with a neighbor to whom he has to pay compensation.) (4) His adoptive son is willing to execute him, when an execu-tioner is not available. (5) His hosts are annoyed by his numerous visits & offer him bad meals (mindful of his father’s advice, he keeps a sample). (6) He passes the night in a forbidden house (where a red-haired man lives). After taking a shortcut, he finds himself in a den of thieves. He escapes (with the help of a servant whom he later marries). (7) He finds out that the woman he intends to marry has a lover (he keeps his trousers as evidence). (8) He lets his wife go to a wedding with her family & her new-born child. Disguised himself as a Turk, he meets her & tries to seduce her & takes her son away. His mother-in-law sets fire to the house & says that the child was killed in the fire. The husband re turns the child & forgives his wife. (9) Nobody wants to buy his horse because the price is too high. It falls sick (is injured) & dies (he keeps the skin as evidence). (10) His mare, which his friend had borrowed, dies from over-work. When his friend apologizes for his mistake he forgives him. Finally he realizes that his father’s precepts were indeed wise. (1) Just before he is arrested, he shows the judge where to find the victim. (2) To his astonishment, it is an animal. (3) It turns out that the missing person (animal) is still alive. (4) He explains that he had only intended to test the precepts of his father. (5) He is immediately freed & prosecutes the persons who tried to harm him. (6) He invites his bride & his parents to his home. (7) He explains to them the significance of the souvenirs of his errors. (8) He casts off his bride.

A poor man who cannot provide for his family takes service with a rich farmer for one year for a certain amount of money. After he has completed his service, the farmer gives him his choice of the agreed wages or a good precept. The man chooses the precept: “Always follow the main road”. Disappointed by this he hires on for a second & then a third year after which he is given various precepts: “Mind your own business” or “Do not sleep where a young woman is married to an old man” & “Always postpone your anger until the next day”. Feeling discouraged the poor man gets ready to go home. His master gives him a loaf of bread (with money hidden inside) which he should not cut until he reaches home. At a fork in the road the poor man follows the farmer’s advice & takes the old main road instead of a shorter new one. He later learns that he would have been waylaid by robbers on the new road. At dusk he reaches a house where he spends the night. There he sees strange events, but he does not interfere. When he is about to leave, his host calls him back & rewards him with a large sum of money for his discretion (indiscretion would have brought death to the host’s wife). After he has refused to sleep in a house where a young woman is married to an old man, he witnesses a murder. When an innocent man, who spent the night at the woman’s house, is condemned for the murder, he testifies to the man’s innocence. When the poor man finally reaches home & looks through a window, he sees a stranger kissing his wife. He intends to kill the man, but fortunately postpones his anger at the last moment. The stranger was his own grown son. When the family gathers around the table to celebrate their reunion, the poor man cuts the bread & finds all the money he had earned hidden inside.

Classifications: Think Carefully Before You Begin a Task
Variation Example: In the market (public place) a young man (king, prince) meets an old (wise) man in a shop where “wisdom” is told instead of goods. The old man explains to the wondering young man that the “wisdom” he sells would be very useful for ruling people. The young man decides to buy a precept for five coins. The old man gives him the following maxim: “Whatever you do, do wisely & think of the consequences” & he adds that if the young man will follow the precept he will become the most powerful person in the whole kingdom. Upon his father’s death the young man becomes king & orders that the maxim be displayed on all the walls of the palace. When enemies bribe his barber to cut the king’s throat while shaving him, he reads the maxim at the last moment. Afraid of the possible conse-quences, he confesses his intention (and desists from his plan). The value of the precept is recognized.

An officer goes to a barber for a shave. He promises to pay well unless the barber cuts him, in which case the officer will kill him. The barber refuses to shave the officer, & so do the two other bar bers in the shop. Only the apprentice will agree to this bargain. All goes well. As the officer leaves, he asks, “Weren’t you afraid?” The apprentice answers, “No. If I had cut you, I would have cut your throat right away with the razor.”

When he dies, a rich merchant advises his spendthrift son that if ever he spends his entire fortune, he should hang himself from a special nail (beam, hook). After his father dies, the son wastes his inheritance with his friends until he has nothing left. When he tries to hang himself in despair, the nail tears out of the wall & a treasure, which his father had hidden there, falls down. From then on the young man leads a virtuous life (pays his debts).

Classifications: Find the Treasure in Our Vineyard
Variation Example: A poor dying farmer tells his sons that he has hidden a treasure in his vineyard (field, ground). After his death his children dig everywhere & thus loosen the soil of the vineyard. They do not find any treasure but the vineyard becomes very fruitful. (Then they understand their father’s advice.)

Classifications: Quarreling Sons & the Bundle of Twigs
Variation Example: A man (king, farmer) explains to his (quarreling) sons, that a bundle of twigs (sticks, arrows, lances) cannot be broken, whereas separately the pieces are easily broken. Thus he demonstrates the value & the strength of unity. His sons apply the lesson.
